concepts.title: Present Bias
concepts.definition: The tendency to overvalue immediate rewards while undervaluing future benefits. This leads to choosing smaller immediate pleasures over larger delayed rewards.
examples: Buying daily coffee ($5) instead of investing that money ($150/month)
Choosing convenient expensive food over meal planning
Impulse purchases that provide instant gratification
reflection_prompts: What future goal is this spending pattern affecting?
If you saved this amount for 6 months, what could you do with it?
What feeling are you trying to satisfy with these purchases?

concepts.title: Mental Accounting
concepts.definition: Treating money differently based on its source or intended use, rather than recognizing all money has equal value.
examples: Spending bonus money frivolously while being frugal with salary
Keeping savings account while carrying credit card debt
Spending gift cards immediately but saving cash carefully
reflection_prompts: Why do you treat this money differently than your regular income?
What would you do if this were cash in your hand?
Are you optimizing across all your money, or just within buckets?

concepts.title: Anchoring Bias
concepts.definition: Over-relying on the first piece of information (the 'anchor') when making decisions, even if it's irrelevant.
examples: Judging value based on 'original price' during sales
Using credit card limit as spending guideline
Comparing purchases to one expensive item to justify others
reflection_prompts: What's the reference point you're using to judge this purchase?
Is that reference point actually meaningful to your situation?
What would you decide if you had no comparison available?

concepts.title: Emotional Spending
concepts.definition: Making purchases to regulate emotions (stress, boredom, sadness) rather than for the item's utility.
examples: Buying things when bored or lonely
reflection_prompts: What emotion were you feeling before making these purchases?
Did the purchases actually resolve that feeling long-term?
What else could address that emotion without spending?

concepts.title: Sunk Cost Fallacy
concepts.definition: Continuing to invest in something because of past investment, even when it's not rational to continue.
examples: Paying for unused gym membership because 'already paid'
Finishing expensive food when already full
reflection_prompts: If you were deciding today with no history, would you choose this?
Is past spending influencing current decisions?
What's the actual cost of continuing versus stopping?
